Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: First, there is a small group of five roots\footnote{A sixth root, teit- `neighbour', was elicited as inalienable but does not occur in the natural spoken corpus.} which can never occur without a possessive suffix. They all refer to family members, and are listed in~(\ref{exe:fammembers}).
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: (\ref{exe:siepsiep}) and~(\ref{exe:siun}) show siep- `edge' inflected with third-person possessive -un and with both -un and locative =ko. (\ref{exe:kitko}),~(\ref{exe:kitpis}) and~(\ref{exe:kitkadok}) show kit- `top' with locative =ko, -pis `side' and -kadok `side'.
Content 1: \gll mier-gan neba-un kit-pis \textbf{siep∼siep-un} eir-gan | \gls 3PL-both what-3POSS top-side edge∼INTS-3POSS two-both | \glt `Both their whatsits point up, both on the very edge.'
Content 2: \gll mu se koi wat pes=at di=kahalong \textbf{siep-un=ko} | \gls 3PL IAM then coconut shell=OBJ CAUS=spear edge-3POSS=LOC | \glt `Then they put coconut shell on the edge of the spear.'
Content 4: \gll ma \textbf{kit-pis}=i sarat=nin ma \textbf{elak-pis}=i=a barat=et | \gls 3SG top-side=PLNK ascend=NEG 3SG down-side=PLNK=FOC descend=IRR | \glt `It doesn't go up, it goes down.'
Content 5: \gll kewe-un \textbf{kit-kadok} | \gls house-3POSS top-side | \glt `His house is at the top.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Note that nouns with -pis and -kadok can be used predicatively (illustrated for -pis in~\ref{exe:kitpis} and for -kadok in~\ref{exe:kitkadok}), or can be arguments, as illustrated for the object NPs in~(\ref{exe:pisat}) and~(\ref{exe:kosat}).
Content 1: \gll ma \textbf{kit-pis}=i sarat=nin ma \textbf{elak-pis}=i=a barat=et | \gls 3SG top-side=PLNK ascend=NEG 3SG down-side=PLNK=FOC descend=IRR | \glt `It doesn't go up, it goes down.'
Content 2: \gll kewe-un \textbf{kit-kadok} | \gls house-3POSS top-side | \glt `His house is at the top.'
Content 3: \gll kiel-un yuon talawak-pis=at jiet=et | \gls root-3POSS sun east-side=OBJ get=IRR | \glt `If [you] get an east-side root...'
Content 4: \gll dinding kibis-kadok=at mera kosalir=kin | \gls wall shore-side=OBJ then change={\glkin} | \glt `(They) then want to change the shore-side wall.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: These suffixes, like locative =ko and lative =ka, are not exclusive to locational nouns. One example with predicative nouns -pis is given in~(\ref{exe:pis1}).
Content 1: \gll kon kahaman-un kit-\textbf{pis} kon elak-\textbf{pis} ba temun | \gls one bottom-3POSS top-\textbf{side} one down-\textbf{side} but big | \glt `One's bottom is at the top, one is at the bottom, but [it's] big.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Within the group of common nouns, Kalamang has mass nouns and count nouns, which behave differently with respect to quantifiers (§\ref{sec:wcquant}). Mass nouns require a measure noun when quantified with a numeral quantifier. This measure noun occurs between the noun and the quantifier. Examples of mass nouns are granular substances such as nasuena `sugar', os `sand', nd pasa `rice' and liquids such as per `water'. Examples of measure nouns are kiem `basket' and goni `sack'. Mass nouns can be quantified with most quantifiers, except taukon/ikon `a few', which is reserved for count nouns, as in~(\ref{exe:bob}). Their counterpart bolon `a little' is used for mass nouns, as in~(\ref{exe:nasbo}).
Content 1: \gll tumtum \textbf{taukon} me Bobi emun=a kona | \gls children few TOP Bobi mother=FOC see | \glt `A few children, Bobi's mother saw [them].'
Content 2: \gll nasuena \textbf{bolon}-i baran | \gls sugar little-OBJQNT descend | \glt `[You] put a little sugar in.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Verbs preceding eranun `cannot' must be nominalised with -un. A transitive example is given in~(\ref{exe:eranunnmlz}) and an intransitive one in~(\ref{exe:eranunintr}).
Content 1: \gll anggas=at \textbf{tarat-un} eranun | \gls door=OBJ close-NMLZ cannot | \glt `[He/she] cannot close the door.'
Content 2: \gll ma toni o an \textbf{nan-un} eranun | \gls 3SG say EMPH 1SG consume-NMLZ cannot | \glt `He said: ``Oh, I cannot eat.'''

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Attributive\is{attribute!nominal} nouns can be derived from intransitive stative verbs, such as kahenun `length; distance' from kahen `to be far' and tiun (tik-un) `age, period of time' from tik `to be old'. The nouns ririnun `length', derived from ririn `to be tall', and temunun `size', derived from temun `to be big', are used in~(\ref{exe:modnmlz}).
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Three stative verbs possibly contain a fossilised possessive suffix: kinkinun `small', (ci)caun `small' and temun `big'. These still need to be inflected with -un to be used as nouns, as is illustrated for temun in~(\ref{exe:modnmlz}).
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Transitive verbs may also be nominalised with -un. This is especially frequent with loan verbs from Malay, as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:malayloans}).
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: To this list can be added the lexical negative construction sukaun ge or sukaun Verb=\textsc{nin} `to not like' (§\ref{sec:lexicalneg}), derived from Malay suka `to like'. Nominalisation with Kalamang transitive verbs is infrequent, but possible. Consider konenenun `memory' from konenen `to remember' in~(\ref{exe:konenenun}).
Content 1: \gll supaya ma neba-un met se mamun=et [...] \textbf{konenen-un} leng-un | \gls so_that 3SG PH-3POSS DIST.OBJ IAM leave=IRR {} remember-NMLZ village-3POSS | \glt `So that she leaves her whatsit behind, the memories of her village.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: The suffix -et is added to nouns to create agent-denoting nouns, typically describing occupation, residency or origin. It is gender\is{gender} neutral. Though productive, at least on place names\is{names!place names}, it is not very common. Some examples are given in~(\ref{exe:kolet}). Alternatively, origin can be described by adding sontum `person', -ca `man' or -pas `woman' to a noun, as described in §\ref{sec:rhcomp}.
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: There is one corpus example where an agentive noun is derived from a verb, given in~(\ref{exe:kamangett}).\footnote{Several data points suggest a link between agentive nominaliser -et and a more general ``animator''. Many animal names, especially those for insects, end in -et or -let (given in~\ref{exe:letet}). This is not a productive suffix on animal names, and there is no proof of a diachronic relation with the agentive nominaliser -et. However, note also the animate classifier et- (§\ref{sec:clf}). A speculative relation could be made between donenet `black ant' and -nenen `body hair' (`that which is hairy'), and between kalabet `earth worm' and kalawen `soft' (`that which is soft'). Kedederet `k.o. bird' could be derived from an onomatopoeion\is{onomatopoeion}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: A common way to derive nouns is by compounding. Compounds are bases derived from two roots, as introduced in §\ref{sec:compounding}. All Kalamang compounds are endocentric, which means that the category of the whole is identical to that of one of the constituents. Left-headed compounds, where the first constituent is the head, and right-headed\is{headedness} compounds, where the second constituent is the head, both occur, illustrated in~(\ref{exe:threecomps}). They are described in §\ref{sec:lhcomp} and~§\ref{sec:rhcomp}.
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Subtype compounds are those that specify the kind of entity the head noun is. They typically denote plants and animals, as seen in~(\ref{exe:subtype}).
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Other left-headed compounds are made with the nouns pas `woman', canam `man', emun `mother' and tumun `child'. The first two, exemplified in~(\ref{exe:mfcomp}), specify the gender\is{gender} of the head noun, and the second two specify relative size, with emun for big things and tumun for small things. This is always relative to another referent, i.e., having a contrastive function. For example, one may talk about one's kewe tumun `house child', which is a small building on the same ground as one's house. `Mother' and `child' are also often used for pairs, such as the two islands south of the biggest Karas island in~(\ref{exe:lempuangt}). In Malay, they are named after the protagonists of a tale about a dog (anjing) and a cassowary (kasuari) who run into the sea and turn into rocks (narr20 in the corpus). The islands are relatively close to each other, and because of the tale are conceived of as a pair.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Part-whole compounds are compounds where the second constituent is either a bound root which typically specifies a plant part (§\ref{sec:inal}) or a free root (a word) specifying another part-whole relationship. The second constituent is the head and is marked with third-person possessive marker -un. There is no recorded meaning for bel in am belun `nipple' (given in~\ref{exe:ambel}), but there is a stative verb belbel `(of a tip) to be sharp'.
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: (\ref{exe:urkiet}) is a common way to form the meaning `cloud' in Maritime Melanesian\is{Melanesian languages} languages \parencite{schapper2017c}.
Content 1: \gll ur kiet-un | \gls wind faeces-3POSS | \glt `cloud'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: While most body parts are expressed as part-whole compounds, with the help of -un \textsc{3poss}, some can be compounded without overt morphology, as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:nakedcomp}). It is also grammatical to add -un `\textsc{3poss}' to the second constituent.
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Reduplication of nouns that refer to a location can be used to indicate distributivity. (\ref{exe:oskitkit}) and~(\ref{exe:osewep}) are from recordings about where certain plants can be found. (\ref{exe:oskitkit}) has a reduplicated oskeit `beach' (from os `sand' and keit `top'), as well as a reduplicated verb kos `to grow' to indicate distribution or habituality (§\ref{sec:verbred}). (\ref{exe:osewep}) has a reduplicated osep `beach' (perhaps from os `sand' and ep `back').
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll ma osep∼ep=ko Tat me reidak | \gls 3SG beach∼DISTR=LOC Tat TOP much | \glt `It's at the beach. At Tat there are many.'
Content 4: \gll ma osep∼ep=ko Tat me reidak | \gls 3SG beach∼DISTR=LOC Tat TOP much | \glt `It's at the beach. At Tat there are many.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: (\ref{exe:rumrum}) makes use of reduplicated tim `edge; tip' (modifying a plant name) to indicate a path.
Content 1: \gll inier yecie [...] rumrum-tim∼tim mera se pareir | \gls 1DU.EX return {} kind_of_plant-edge∼DISTR then IAM follow | \glt `We returned following the edge of the rumrum plants.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Associative noun-to-noun derivation or noun-to-noun derivation expressing in-between states is rather uncommon. (\ref{exe:donsaun}) illustrates associative derivation.
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: This section considers the behaviour of the different constituents of the NP. Quantifiers, possessive pronouns, attributive predicates and demonstratives follow the head noun. Nominal possessors precede the head noun. Their mutual order is illustrated in~(\ref{exe:npstr}). The place of attributive\is{attribute} predicates is tentative due to a shortage of unambiguous instances in the data.
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Fully saturated NPs such as the one formulated in~(\ref{exe:npstr}) are exceedingly uncommon in the data. There is exactly one natural spoken corpus example with three post-nominal modifiers in the NP, illustrated in~(\ref{exe:dongdong}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll [hukat kon anggon yuwa] me paruo dong∼dong-kaning | \gls net one 1SG.POSS PROX TOP make tense∼INTS-very | \glt `This one net of mine, make it tight.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: %Numerals follow nouns modifying nouns, see example~\ref{exe:nadjnum}.
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Nominal possessors (§\ref{sec:possphr}) precede the possessed noun. (\ref{exe:unyua}) shows a nominal possessor preceding the head noun ming `oil'.
Content 1: \gll ka [nene ming-un yuwa]=at kuet=et | \gls 2SG grandmother oil-3POSS PROX=OBJ bring=IRR | \glt `You bring this oil of granny's.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Quantifiers (introduced in §\ref{sec:wcquantnum}) indicate the quantity of the referent of a NP. They include numeral and non-numeral quantifiers. Quantifiers take the second slot after the noun in the NP, following the possessive suffix. Quantifiers modifying the subject are unmarked, as shown by karuok `three' in~(\ref{exe:ladank}) and ikon `few; some' in~(\ref{exe:emikon}). Quantifiers may carry a classifier prefix, depending on the noun. (\ref{exe:kanase}) shows the classifier ep- for groups of living beings, on the numeral kon `one', modifying kanas `kind of fish'. For more on classifiers, see §\ref{sec:clf}.
Content 1: \gll opa [som \textbf{karuok}] me mambaran kon ladan kerkap | \gls earlier person three TOP stand one shirt red | \glt `Earlier, there were three people standing, one [had] a red shirt.'
Content 2: \gll [emumur \textbf{ikon}] toni ah ma se me | \gls woman.PL some say INT 3SG IAM DIST | \glt `Some of the women say: ``Ah, that's it.'''
Content 3: \gll [kanas \textbf{ep-kon}]=a marua ime | \gls kind_of_fish CLF_GROUP-one=FOC move_seawards DIST | \glt `A school of kanas moves towards that [part of] the sea!'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Quantifiers modifying the object carry a special object marker, -i\is{quantifier object}, while the object is marked with the object postposition =at (see §\ref{sec:at}). In these cases, the quantifiers appear to be outside the PP, as tentatively indicated in~(\ref{exe:kanye}) and~(\ref{exe:mingtunat}).\is{postpositional phrase}
Content 1: \gll in marua [pas kanyot=at] \textbf{kansuor-i} koluk | \gls 1PL.EXCL move_seawards exactly giant_clam=OBJ four-OBJQNT find | \glt `We went to sea and found four giant clams right there.'
Content 2: \gll [mingtun=at] \textbf{bolon-i} ko=yuon | \gls coconut_oil=OBJ little-OBJQNT APPL=rub | \glt `[You] rub a little coconut oil on.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: In NPs which contain a quantifier and another modifier occupying a later slot, however, the quantifier does not carry -i \textsc{objqnt}. In~(\ref{exe:nairmet}), the demonstrative (which is the last possible element of the NP) carries object marking, and the quantifiers again appear to be inside the NP.
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: The head noun can be elided when the nominal referent can be retrieved from the context, so that the \is{numeral}numeral becomes the head of the NP. This is shown in~(\ref{exe:ladank}) above for kon `one' and eir `two' in~(\ref{exe:eirnau}), where the two animals have been extensively referred to earlier in the conversation, and are visible in pictures in front of the speakers. In~(\ref{exe:mekua}), the numeral head is modified by a demonstrative.
Content 1: \gll opa [som \textbf{karuok}] me mambaran kon ladan kerkap | \gls earlier person three TOP stand one shirt red | \glt `Earlier, there were three people standing, one [had] a red shirt.'
Content 2: \gll [\textbf{eir}] nau=namanghadap | \gls two RECP=face | \glt `Two [animals] face each other.'
Content 3: \gll [kon wa] me kuat=nin | \gls one PROX TOP strong=NEG | \glt `This one isn't strong.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: The quantifier object marker also remains in place if the object is elided, as in~(\ref{exe:nuru}).
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: In a few cases, numeral quantifiers form a compound\is{compound} with the noun. (\ref{exe:yuolreitkon}) has the compound yuol reitkon `the hundredth day', which is an important day in the commemoration of deceased people. The fact that it is a compound is evidenced by the object marker on the numeral.
Content 1: \gll tok [yuol \textbf{reitkon}]\textbf{=at=a} nawanggar | \gls still day hundred=OBJ=FOC wait | \glt `[We are] still waiting for the hundredth day.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Besides nominal possessors, there are two adnominal markers of possession: nominal possessive suffixes and freestanding possessive pronouns. They are described in detail in Chapter~\ref{ch:poss}. Possessive suffixes attach to the head noun, as in~(\ref{exe:keweant}).
Content 1: \gll an [kewe-an temun]=at paruo | \gls 1SG house-1SG.POSS big=OBJ make | \glt `I am making my big house.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Possessive pronouns occupy a slot between head nouns and demonstratives (more precisely, between quantifiers and attributively used verbs, but no example illustrating this is available). (\ref{exe:gamka}) illustrates a possessive pronoun preceding a demonstrative.
Content 1: \gll [gambar kain yuwane] | \gls picture 2SG.POSS PROX | \glt `this picture of yours'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: (\ref{exe:demadd}) and~(\ref{exe:pulorc}) illustrate the proximal and distal forms. In~(\ref{exe:demadd}), the speaker points to a woman in a picture in front of him, and uses the proximal form to modify enem `woman'. In~(\ref{exe:pulorc}), pulor-ca `your betel', which is not currently visible, is modified with the distal demonstrative me. In~(\ref{exe:donowa}), the far distal owa is used to modify don `thing', which refers to a herb which one can collect at a neighbouring beach.
Content 1: \gll ma [enem \textbf{wat}]=a tu | \gls 3SG woman PROX.OBJ=FOC hit | \glt `He hits this woman.'
Content 2: \gll an [pulor-ca \textbf{met}] parua=ta | \gls 1SG betel_vine-2SG.POSS DIST.OBJ pluck=NFIN | \glt `I plucked that betel vine of yours.'
Content 3: \gll ma [enem \textbf{wat}]=a tu | \gls 3SG woman PROX.OBJ=FOC hit | \glt `He hits this woman.'
Content 4: \gll an [pulor-ca \textbf{met}] parua=ta | \gls 1SG betel_vine-2SG.POSS DIST.OBJ pluck=NFIN | \glt `I plucked that betel vine of yours.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: The demonstrative opa modifies goras `crow' in~(\ref{exe:gorasopa}), indicating that the crow being referred to is the same one that was mentioned earlier in the story.
Content 1: \gll [goras \textbf{opa}] melelu ror-kitko kome bara∼bara | \gls crow ANA sit tree-top.LOC look down∼PROG | \glt `That crow sits in the tree looking down.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: NPs with demonstratives almost never contain other nominal modifiers; (\ref{exe:dongdong}) above is one of the few in the corpus.\is{demonstrative|)}
Content 1: \gll [hukat kon anggon yuwa] me paruo dong∼dong-kaning | \gls net one 1SG.POSS PROX TOP make tense∼INTS-very | \glt `This one net of mine, make it tight.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: All verbal predicates can be used attributively (§\ref{sec:wcverb}). Attributive clitic =ten is attached to predicates when they are used attributively both in subject position, as in~(\ref{exe:attradj}a), and in object position, as in~(\ref{exe:attradj}b). See also §\ref{sec:wcverb}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Often, predicates modifying a noun carry the attributive marker =ten. Examples include the locative leng=ko `in the village' in~(\ref{exe:lengkoren}), reduplicated towari `young' in~(\ref{exe:towawa}) and lu `cold' in~(\ref{exe:luren}). However, common attributes like colours, (ci)caun/kin\-kinun `small' and temun `big' may modify a noun without the use of =ten, exemplified for kinkinun `small' in~(\ref{exe:rorkin}) (see also §\ref{sec:wcverb}).
Content 1: \gll mungkin proyek kegiatan \textbf{leng=ko=ten} | \gls maybe project activity village=LOC=AT | \glt `Or maybe a project with an activity that is in the village.'
Content 2: \gll pebis \textbf{towari∼wa=ten} mara | \gls woman young∼RED=AT move_landwards | \glt `The young women came to the shore.'
Content 3: \gll se pasa \textbf{lu=ten=at} nan=i koyet | \gls IAM rice cold=AT=OBJ consume=PLNK finish | \glt `After eating cold rice...'
Content 4: \gll ror \textbf{kinkinun} saerak | \gls wood small NEG_EXIST | \glt `There is no small wood.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: The position of attributively used predicates in the NP appears to be between possessive pronouns and demonstratives. There are corpus examples that show an attributive predicate after a noun modifying a noun as in (\ref{exe:yarpos}), after a quantifier as in (\ref{exe:ar1}) and after a possessive marker as in (\ref{exe:esatem}), as well as before a demonstrative as in (\ref{exe:tuaren0}) and (\ref{exe:pepun}).
Content 1: \gll mu in=at pareir bo yar-pos nerunggo [yar-pos temun] o | \gls 3PL 1PL.EXCL=OBJ follow go rock-hole inside.LOC rock-hole big EMPH | \glt `They followed us inside the hole, a big hole.'
Content 2: \gll inier bo ror opa temun [ror ar-kon temun] | \gls 2DU.EX go tree ANA big tree CLF_STEM-one big | \glt `We went [to] the big tree, the big tree.'
Content 3: \gll [esa anggon temun=a] an=at gonggung | \gls father 1SG.POSS big=FOC 1SG=OBJ call | \glt `My father's older brother calls me.'
Content 4: \gll [sontum tua=ten opa me] Ayah Panggil esun ma mat terima | \gls person old=AT {\glopa} TOP Ayah Panggil father.3POSS 3SG 3SG.OBJ welcome | \glt `That old person, Ayah Panggil's father welcomes her.'
Content 5: \gll mu [pep-un karuar=ten met] nan=i koyet | \gls 3SG pig-3POSS smoke_dry=AT DIST.OBJ consume=PLNK finish | \glt `He ate their smoked pig.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: What is expressed by relativised clauses in some languages is typically done with biclausal constructions or non-final constructions in Kalamang. This is reflected in elicitation. In~(\ref{exe:jenden}), the speaker was asked for a translation of `this thing I bought was bad' (Malay barang ini yang saya beli tidak bagus), and gave a biclausal construction linked by conjunction ba `but'. (\ref{exe:komeraa}) is the translation given for `the children that I saw went to sea' (Malay anak yang saya lihat pi di laut), and is a biclausal construction involving the verb kome `to see' marked with non-final =ta.
Content 1: \gll tumun opa me an kome=\textbf{ta}, mu wilak=ka marua | \gls child {\glopa} TOP 1SG see=NFIN 3PL sea=LAT move_seawards | \glt `Having seen those children, they went to sea.'
Content 2: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Object NPs are marked with =at. We see this for the first-person singular an in~(\ref{exe:anara}), or ror `wood' and sontum et-un `person's canoe' in~(\ref{exe:erunat}). Object marking is obligatory for all object NPs except those marked with the topic marker me; see §\ref{sec:discme}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Both direct and indirect objects of certain ditransitive verbs, such as kiempanaet `to send' in~(\ref{exe:kiempa}), are marked with =at (see also §\ref{sec:give}). In elicited examples, we can find two instances of =at in one clause. In the natural spoken corpus, there are no examples with a direct and indirect object marked with =at, because either the theme or the recipient tends to be dropped.
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Demonstratives in the rightmost position of an object NP have phonologically fused forms: proximal wa is wat and distal me is met (Chapter~\ref{ch:dems}). Their underlying forms are given in~(\ref{exe:watt}) and~(\ref{exe:mett}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: If the rightmost position in the NP is occupied by a quantifier, =at attaches to the last word before the quantifier. The latter receives its own object marking. In~(\ref{exe:konii}), the quantifiers appear to be outside of the NP. However, see §\ref{sec:nmodqnt} for quantifiers inside the NP.
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Comitative =bon typically expresses accompaniment. If both members of a pair are mentioned they are usually both marked with comitative =bon, as in~(\ref{exe:kiunbon}). When a dual pronoun is followed by a noun marked with =bon it refers to two people, not three, as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:konbon}). The dual is in that case not marked with the comitative.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll terus ter-nan=i koyet inier tamu kon=\textbf{bon} misis wis go_dung | \gls then tea-consume=PLNK finish 1DU guest one=\TEXTBF{COM} miss yesterday morning | \glt `Then we finished drinking tea, me and a guest, miss, yesterday morning.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: The marker =bon is also used to express more abstract meanings, such as `with' in `to be busy with work' and `chat with', illustrated in~(\ref{exe:karajangbon}) and~(\ref{exe:mebon}).
Content 1: \gll sontum saerak sontum tok sibuk karajang=\textbf{bon} | \gls person NEG_EXIST person still busy work=\TEXTBF{COM} | \glt `There are no people, people are still busy with work.'
Content 2: \gll kiar opa me ma ra canam me=\textbf{bon} garung | \gls wife {\glopa} TOP 3SG go man DIST=COM chat | \glt `That wife, she went to chat with that man.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: In object function, =bon must be followed by the object marker =at as in~(\ref{exe:bonat}).
Content 1: \gll ma kaden-un=bon nakal-un=\textbf{bon=at} maling=i taikon | \gls 3SG body-3POSS=COM head-3POSS=COM=OBJ tilt=PLNK side | \glt `He tilts his body and his head to one side.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: In a few corpus instances bon stands on its own, with the complement elided but retrievable from the context. (\ref{exe:hebonbon}) is taken from a conversation\is{conversation} about how to prepare a dish with certain leaves. Speaker A mentions a coconut, whereupon speaker B says it should be grated and mixed with the leaves. Both the leaves and the coconut can be retrieved from the context, and so bon can stand on its own. This, and the fact that =bon can be combined with other postpositions, suggests that it is slightly different from the other postpositions.
Content 1: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Instrumental =ki indicates that the NP head is the means or the instrument with which an action is achieved. This can be very literal, such as the instrument gier `tooth' in~(\ref{exe:kareat}) to cut a string, or more abstract, such as the mode of transport pesawat `aeroplane' in~(\ref{exe:pesawat}). It is also used with the noun mang `language', to express that someone uses that language, as in~(\ref{exe:walakamang}). Finally, (\ref{exe:minggi}) shows the distal instrumental demonstrative minggi `with that', where =ki is fused with the distal demonstrative root (§\ref{sec:demcase}).
Content 1: \gll ma karek=at tolma to ma gier=\textbf{ki} tolma | \gls 3SG string=OBJ cut right 3SG tooth=INS cut | \glt `She cut the string, right, she cut [it] with her teeth.'
Content 2: \gll ma owa=ba pesawat=\textbf{ki} mia | \gls 3SG FDIST=FOC aeroplane=INS come | \glt `She comes from over there by aeroplane.'
Content 4: \gll ripi putkon=kin \textbf{minggi} winyal | \gls thousand ten=POSS DIST.INS fish_with_line | \glt `[Fishing line that costs] ten thousand, with that you go line-fishing.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Benefactive =ki only occurs in give-constructions, where it attaches to the nominal recipient, as in~(\ref{exe:tetenggi}). It cannot be used on pronominal recipients. Give-con\-struc\-tions are described in more detail in §\ref{sec:give}.
Content 1: \gll sor me selet-kon-i tete=\textbf{ki} ∅=te | \gls fish TOP piece-one-OBJQNT grandfather.MLY=\TEXTBF{BEN} give=IMP | \glt `The fish, give a piece of it to grandfather!'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Similative =kap attaches to NPs whose quality is compared to a standard (see also §\ref{sec:sim}). It attaches to predicative nouns (example~\ref{exe:perkapteba}) and pronouns (example~\ref{exe:anggap}), but not to demonstratives. Demonstratives have dedicated manner forms used in a similar vein to the similative: proximal wandi `like this' and distal mindi `like that' (Chapter~\ref{ch:dems}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll kat paruo me sama=i nain an=kap | \gls 2SG.OBJ make TOP same=PLNK like 1SG=SIM | \glt `Make you the same as me.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Locative =ko specifies inanimate locations (for animate locative =konggo, see §\ref{sec:animloclat}). (\ref{exe:pepkaden}) contains two locatives: `on top of the pig's body' and `on his back'. In (\ref{exe:pork}), the locative NP consists of of a noun and a demonstrative.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: NPs with locative postpositions =ko or =konggo are commonly used predicatively, as in~(\ref{exe:locpred}), where there is no verb in the clause and the location `Wagom' marked with the locative postposition translates as `be in Wagom'. When used predicatively, \mbox{=ko} is inflected accordingly with e.g. the negator =nin (example~\ref{exe:kolaonin}) or \is{imperative}imperative =te (example~\ref{exe:orkore}).
Content 1: \gll an Wagom=\textbf{ko} | \gls 1SG Wagom=LOC | \glt `I was in Wagom.'
Content 2: \gll ma kolak=\textbf{ko}=\textbf{nin} ma pasier=ko | \gls 3SG mainland=LOC=NEG 3SG sea=LOC | \glt `She wasn't on the mainland, she was in the sea.'
Content 3: \gll ka me or=\textbf{ko}=\textbf{te} | \gls 2SG TOP back=LOC=IMP | \glt `You go in the back!'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Locatives may occur with verbs, although no verb requires a locative complement. Some verbs, like ecie `to return' and bo `to go', must precede a locative (\ref{exe:Vloc}), and occur in constructions where movement towards a goal is expressed, rather than location. It is only in these instances where the locative is used in movement contexts that the locative may be inflected for imperative mood (§\ref{sec:imp}). Other verbs, like melelu `to sit', follow the locative (\ref{exe:locV}). The behaviour of different verbs with locatives is further described in §\ref{sec:svcloclat}.
Content 1: \gll tebonggan koi ecien=i kewe=\textbf{ko} | \gls everyone then return=PLNK house=LOC | \glt `Then everyone returned home.'
Content 2: \gll ma bakul kon bol-un=\textbf{ko} melelu | \gls 3SG basket one mouth-3POSS=LOC sit | \glt `He sits on the rim of a basket.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: There are two ways to mark NPs with locative =ko \parencite[cf.][]{huber2018}. When there is no ambiguity with regard to the location of the referent, or when the location is big or generic, =ko can be attached to a NP consisting of just a noun. This applies to place names\is{names!place names} (see \ref{exe:locpred}), landscape features such as kolak `forest; mountain; mainland' or pasier `sea' (see \ref{exe:kolaonin}) and kewe `house' (see \ref{exe:Vloc}). With smaller and more specific nouns, like bakul `basket' (see \ref{exe:locV}) or kaden `body' (see \ref{exe:pepkaden}), the exact location has to be specified with the help of a relational noun. These nouns are commonly inflected with possessive suffix -un and and then followed by locative =ko (see Table~\ref{tab:locationals} in §\ref{sec:inal}). These roots cannot stand alone as a subject, object or location, but must be inflected with possessive -un, locative =ko, both -un and =ko, -pis `side', or -kadok `side'. Alternatively, they may be followed by a local demonstrative, as in~(\ref{exe:elak}).
Content 1: \gll an Wagom=\textbf{ko} | \gls 1SG Wagom=LOC | \glt `I was in Wagom.'
Content 2: \gll ma kolak=\textbf{ko}=\textbf{nin} ma pasier=ko | \gls 3SG mainland=LOC=NEG 3SG sea=LOC | \glt `She wasn't on the mainland, she was in the sea.'
Content 3: \gll tebonggan koi ecien=i kewe=\textbf{ko} | \gls everyone then return=PLNK house=LOC | \glt `Then everyone returned home.'
Content 4: \gll ma bakul kon bol-un=\textbf{ko} melelu | \gls 3SG basket one mouth-3POSS=LOC sit | \glt `He sits on the rim of a basket.'
Content 6: \gll kofir bungkus kon \textbf{elak} \textbf{metko} | \gls coffee pack one bottom DIST.LOC | \glt `There is a pack of coffee at the bottom there.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: At this point, it is not clear whether, for example, scale or absolute distance between the referents plays a role in the choice of frame of reference \parencite{levinson2006}. In any case, different frames of reference may be combined in order to get a message across, as in~(\ref{exe:kibisunggo}).
Content 1: \gll ma ror kibis-un=\textbf{ko} mambara tanbes=\textbf{ko} | \gls 3SG tree shore-3POSS=LOC stand right=LOC | \glt `He stands to the shore-side of the tree, on the right.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: There are a few unexpected uses of the locational root keit- `top' inflected with the locative. These are yuonggeitko `in the sun', but literally `on the sun' (example~\ref{exe:yuong}), and naunggeitko `in the soil', but literally `on the soil' (example~\ref{exe:naungg}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll ma ewun naun-keit=\textbf{ko}=nin | \gls 3SG root soil-top=LOC=NEG | \glt `Its roots don't go in the soil.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Lative =ka specifies movement from (ab-lative) or towards (al-lative) an inanimate location (for animate lative =kongga, see §\ref{sec:animloclat}). In contrast with NPs marked with =ko, NPs marked with a lative postposition cannot be predicative: they must be accompanied by a verb, which always follows the NP marked with =ka. In~(\ref{exe:kelaka}), =ka means `from' and is combined with the verb gonggung `call'. In~(\ref{exe:telin}), =ka means `to' and is combined with the verb bo `to go'. See also §\ref{sec:svcloclat}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Like locative =ko, lative =ka occurs on demonstratives and the question word tama, forming the fused forms wangga `to/from here' (example~\ref{exe:bilal}), mengga `to/from there' (example~\ref{exe:silak}) and tamangga `to/from where'. See also §\ref{sec:problems} and Chapter~\ref{ch:dems}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll ma \textbf{tamangga}=ta tiri bot | \gls 3SG where.LAT=NFIN swim go | \glt `Where did it swim?'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: The locative and lative postpositions that attach to animate NPs are =konggo and =kongga, respectively. They attach to NPs with pronouns referring to animates, animate nouns and names\is{names!personal names}. The locative postposition =ko and lative =ka are ungrammatical with animate NPs. Consider~(\ref{exe:tete}) and~(\ref{exe:bilal}).
Content 1: \gll ma se ra paning tete=konggo | \gls 3SG IAM go ask grandfather=AN.LOC | \glt `He went to ask grandfather.'
Content 2: Not found

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Animate locative =konggo is used, besides indicating location at an animate referent (as in \ref{exe:konggo1} and~\ref{exe:konggo3}), for the recipient of \is{greeting}greetings (`greet at him', example~\ref{exe:konggo4}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll an=\textbf{konggo} me ror tantayon=ko ma tanbes=ko | \gls 1SG=AN.LOC TOP tree left=LOC 3SG right=LOC | \glt `Mine [my picture] has the tree on the left and him on the right.'
Content 3: \gll kirim salam mu=\textbf{konggo} | \gls send greetings 3PL=AN.LOC | \glt `Send greetings to them!'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Animate lative =kongga, besides indicating movement towards/from an animate referent (as in \ref{exe:kongga2}), is used for constructions expressing the referent's opinion or will (\ref{exe:kongga3}) and for constructions with `tell' (\ref{exe:kainkon}).
Content 1: \gll in kiem=i Jepang in=\textbf{kongga} luk weinun | \gls 1PL.EXCL flee=PLNK Japan 1PL.EXCL=AN.LAT come too | \glt `We fled and the Japanese came to us too.'
Content 2: \gll sabar kuawi goras=\textbf{kongga} | \gls front north crow=AN.LAT | \glt `Whether [the boat] points north depends on the crow.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: The corpus contains three instances of animate locative =konggo on inanimate NPs: once on but `stairs', once on semen `cement' and once on muka `front'. Although the latter two are Malay loans, there are no further indications that loan words have an influence on the use of the animate locative. In~(\ref{exe:butkon}) and~(\ref{exe:semenkon}), the animate locative is followed by a distal locative. This does not explain the use of an animate locative on an inanimate either, as the inanimate locative =ko followed by a distal locative occurs elsewhere in the corpus. Animate lative =kongga does not occur on inanimate NPs.
Content 1: \gll kuru marua paruak=i but=konggo imetko | \gls bring move_seawards throw_away=PLNK stairs=AN.LOC DIST.LOC | \glt `[They] brought [the fishing net] seawards and threw it at the stairs there.'
Content 2: \gll nam∼nam=i mia semen=konggo metko | \gls puddle∼PROG=PLNK come cement=AN.LOC DIST.LOC | \glt `[The blood] came puddling on the cement there.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Conjunctive coordination is signalled with the comitative postposition\is{postposition!comitative} =bon, as described in §\ref{sec:comi}, or without overt marking. Conjunctive coordination may be unmarked in lists, such as the list of food items in~(\ref{exe:impan}). There is an intonation\is{intonation} break after every noun.
Content 1: \gll im panggala yap_seran manadu pasiem met=a in na∼nan | \gls banana cassava yam taro banana DIST=FOC 1PL.EXCL consume∼HAB | \glt `Banana, cassava, yam, taro, banana, that's what we used to eat.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Disjunctive coordination is signalled with ye `or'. It typically follows all coordinated elements, including the last one. Intonationally, ye `or' belongs to the preceding constituent. The disjunctive coordinator is not limited to coordinating NPs, but may coordinate clauses as well. An example coordinating three proper names\is{names!personal names} is given in~(\ref{exe:iwan}).
Content 1: \gll Unyil \textbf{ye} Arif \textbf{ye} Iwan \textbf{ye} | \gls Unyil or Arif or Iwan or | \glt `Unyil, Arif or Iwan?'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: Ye `or' may also only follow the first NP, as in~(\ref{exe:masaret}), still belonging to that constituent intonationally.
Content 1: \gll wan-karuok \textbf{ye} wan-kansuor masat=et ma se kararak | \gls time-three or time-four dry_in_sun=IRR 3SG IAM dry | \glt `[After] drying in the sun three or four times, it's already dry.'

Chapter: Nouns, noun phrases and postpositional phrases
Knowledge Point: In a few cases (eight examples in the natural spoken language corpus), the Kalamang coordinator ye `or' is combined with the Malay equivalent atau `or', as in~(\ref{exe:yeatau}). Intonationally, atau also belongs to the constituent it follows.
Content 1: \gll pi se muap=at nain amdir=at paruo panggala \textbf{ye} \textbf{atau} im \textbf{ye} pasiem | \gls 1PL.INCL IAM food=OBJ like garden=OBJ make cassava or or banana or yellow_taro | \glt `We make a food garden, [with] cassava, banana or yellow taro.'
